sections.heading: 〜出す (dasu) - Start Doing
sections.content:
〜出す attaches to verb stems to indicate the sudden or spontaneous beginning of an action. Unlike 始める which is neutral, 出す emphasizes that something starts abruptly or unexpectedly.

Verb stem + 出す 走り出す - start running (suddenly) 泣き出す - start crying (suddenly) 降り出す - start falling (rain/snow) Emphasis: Sudden start Unexpected beginning

children.heading: Basic pattern
children.content: る-verbs: 食べる → 食べ出す "start eating suddenly" 見る → 見出す "start watching suddenly" う-verbs: 走る → 走り出す "start running suddenly" 泣く → 泣き出す "start crying suddenly" 降る → 降り出す "start falling suddenly" Irregular: する → し出す "start doing suddenly" 来る → 来出す (rare)

children.heading: Sudden beginning
children.content: 雨が降り出した "It started raining (suddenly)" Implies: Wasn't raining, then suddenly was Not gradual, but abrupt start 子供が泣き出した "The child started crying" Implies: Sudden onset of crying Unexpected or quick start

children.heading: Weather
children.content: 雨が降り出す "rain starts falling" 雪が降り出す "snow starts falling" 風が吹き出す "wind starts blowing" Natural phenomena Sudden weather changes Very common usage

children.heading: Emotions
children.content: 泣き出す "start crying" 笑い出す "start laughing" 怒り出す "start getting angry" Emotional outbursts Sudden reactions

children.heading: Physical actions
children.content: 走り出す "start running" 歩き出す "start walking" 動き出す "start moving" Sudden movement Beginning motion

children.heading: Speech
children.content: 話し出す "start talking" 歌い出す "start singing" 叫び出す "start shouting" Beginning to speak/sing Often suddenly

children.heading: Compare with 始める
children.content: 話し始める "begin talking" Neutral, planned 話し出す "start talking (suddenly)" Abrupt, unplanned 食べ始める "begin eating" Normal start 食べ出す "start eating (suddenly)" Unexpected start, perhaps rudely

children.heading: Usually becomes intransitive
children.content: Even if base verb is transitive: 読む (transitive) → 読み出す Often used intransitively: 本を読み出す (less common) 急に読み出した "suddenly started reading" The 出す compound emphasizes the action itself Object often omitted

children.heading: Natural contexts
children.content: 会議中に笑い出した "Started laughing during the meeting" Implies: Inappropriate timing いきなり走り出した "Suddenly started running" Implies: Without warning 雨が降り出したから帰ろう "It started raining so let's go home" Implies: Sudden weather change

children.heading: Movement verbs
children.content: 飛び出す "jump out, dash out" 飛び込む (base) → 飛び出す Burst out suddenly 転がり出す "start rolling" Roll and exit/emerge

children.heading: Discovery/realization
children.content: 見出す "discover, find out" Special meaning here Not just "start seeing" But "discover" or "recognize value" 才能を見出す "discover talent"

children.heading: Beginning processes
children.content: 動き出す "start moving" (machines, vehicles) 車が動き出した "The car started moving" 機械が動き出す "The machine starts operating" Mechanical or large-scale movement

children.heading: Uncontrolled or natural
children.content: 笑い出す Often can't help it Spontaneous laughter 泣き出す Bursting into tears Not planned crying Implies lack of full control Natural, spontaneous reaction

children.heading: Immediate beginning
children.content: Focus on the moment action starts: 急に降り出した "Suddenly started falling" The moment it began Not the continuation Emphasizes start point

children.heading: Frequent combinations
children.content: 降り出す (rain/snow) Most common with weather 泣き出す (crying) Very common emotional 走り出す (running) Common physical action 笑い出す (laughing) Common reaction These are natural, established Learn as set phrases

children.heading: Regular る-verb conjugation
children.content: 降り出す: Present: 降り出す Past: 降り出した Negative: 降り出さない Te-form: 降り出して Potential: 降り出せる Conjugates like any る-verb Second verb determines conjugation

children.heading: Example patterns
children.content: Noun が Verb-出す: 雨が降り出した "Rain started falling" 子供が泣き出した "Child started crying" いきなり/急に + Verb-出す: いきなり走り出した "Suddenly started running" 急に笑い出した "Suddenly started laughing" Emphasizing suddenness Natural sentence patterns

children.heading: Neutral formality
children.content: Can be used in: - Casual conversation - Formal speech - Writing Formality comes from: - Conjugation style - Context - Surrounding grammar Not inherently casual or formal

sections.heading: Common Mistakes
sections.content: ❌ Using for planned actions ✗ 明日から勉強し出す (use 始める instead) "Start studying from tomorrow" ✓ Use for spontaneous actions ✓ 急に勉強し出した "Suddenly started studying" ❌ Overusing where 始める fits Choose based on nuance ✓ Match verb to context Sudden → 出す Neutral → 始める

children.heading: Some compounds have unique meanings
children.content: 見出す Not "start seeing" But "discover, find" 思い出す Not "start thinking" But "remember, recall" These are lexicalized Learn as separate vocabulary Different from regular pattern
